title: Autophagy's role in health and disease prevention
content: Eileen White describes the fundamental role of autophagy in the maintenance of health and prevention of neurodegeneration, cancer, and other diseases.

title: Autophagy's paradoxical effect on cancer cells
content: Eileen White goes into detail about the paradoxical finding that autophagy may benefit an existing cancer cell and help it to survive—a discovery leading to new possibilities in cancer therapy.

title: Fasting and autophagy
content: Eileen White and Peter Attia discuss fasting (and molecules that induce autophagy) and the critical need to decode the proper fasting “dose” in order to improve human health.

title: #247 ‒ Preventing cardiovascular disease: the latest in diagnostic imaging, blood pressure, metabolic health, and more
content: In this episode, Ethan Weiss, M.D. discusses the latest in diagnostic imaging, blood pressure, metabolic health, and more in preventing cardiovascular disease.

title: #244 ‒ The history of the cell, cell therapy, gene therapy, and more
content: In this episode, Siddhartha Mukherjee talks about the history of the cell, cell therapy, gene therapy, and more.

title: #243 ‒ The fentanyl crisis and why everyone should be paying attention
content: In this episode, Anthony Hipolito discusses the fentanyl crisis and why everyone should be paying attention.

title: The Physiology of Stress Response
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the widespread impact of stress on our physical and emotional health as well as the mechanisms by which it can precipitate chronic illness, dementia, depression, and more. He also provides insight into the factors that contribute to the stress response (and our ability to handle it) such as social rank, personality, environment, and genetics.

title: The Impact of Stress on Health
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the impact of stress on atherosclerosis, dementia, addiction, and depression. He also talks about the role of stress in cancer and how it can lead to chronic illness.

title: Tips for Managing Stress
content: Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., provides tips for managing stress in the modern world. He talks about the impact of subjective socioeconomic status and social media on stress levels and health.

title: Eileen's Background and Career
content: Eileen got a Ph.D. in biology and studied in the department led by Dr. Arnie Levine, who discovered p53. She then went to Cold Spring Harbor Lab where she got a postdoc with Bruce Stillman. She then went to Rutgers to be on the faculty. Shortly after that, they hired a cancer center director, Bill Hait, and she and Bill helped to build what’s now the Rutgers Cancer Institute.

title: Defining Apoptosis and Its Role in Cancer Prevention
content: Apoptosis is triggered by the core apoptotic machinery that resides in the mitochondrial membrane. Bcl-xL and other inhibitors of apoptosis are trying to antagonize this process. Mitochondrial damage can certainly trigger apoptosis. p53 is a tumor suppressor and one of the functions is to promote apoptosis to prevent an emerging cancer cell from progressing. Mutations in p53 accounts for about half of all cancers.

title: Autophagy in cancer cells
content: When we disable apoptosis in a cancer cell, it can’t commit suicide and tumor cells become more tumorigenic. They then discovered that these cells had turned on autophagy and we’re using that for survival. Autophagosomes were already known to exist in cells in mammals. However, there was almost no information on autophagy and cancer at the time. Inhibiting autophagy reduced the survival of cancer cells. Normal cells in the fed state don’t have autophagy “on”… it functions at a very, very low level. But if you starved cells for nutrients, then there’s a massive upregulation of autophagy. What was striking about the cancer setting was… even in the fed state, autophagy was elevated. And then if you stress cancer cells, it goes up even further.

title: Apoptosis vs Necrosis
content: In apoptosis, you have proteolytic degradation of a cell and packaging it into these bodies and you say, ‘Well, does that limit inflammation?” Well, when you compare it to a different form of cell death like necrosis… Necrosis is very proinflammatory ⇒ nucleic acids are released and mitochondrial content is released (which is probably the most immunogenic given its bacterial origin of the DNA). Apoptosis is much “cleaner” than necrosis.

title: Post apoptosis
content: You would get protein degradation and packaging of pieces of the dead cells into these apoptotic bodies. And then that would reduce inflammation. There’s evidence that macrophages can then go and take up these apoptotic bodies and that may facilitate antigen presentation. Yes, says Eileen, “I think something like that occurs”.

title: Metabolism of cancer cells
content: The metabolism of a cancer cell is designed to facilitate de novo synthesis of nucleotides. A common observation is that nucleotides seem to be rate limiting. Another observation is that the autophagy pathway can “eat” ribosomes… Evolution preserved the ability to use autophagy over billions of years… When you compare how yeast does autophagy and how when mammals do autophagy and what they’re using it for… it just looks like the mammalian version of autophagy is a little bit more complicated.

title: Stressors that induce autophagy
content: Three pathways at the mechanistic level: 1—The mTOR pathway, which is mostly sensing amino acids 2—AMPK pathway, which is mostly sensing energy and ATP in general 3—The Acetyl-CoA protein deacetylation pathway, which is also just basically sensing substrate of fatty acid and glucose. Additionally, stresses that result in i) organelle damage–such as depolarization or dysfunction of mitochondria, ii) activation of protein misfolding, and iii) generation of protein aggregates. Temperature extremes would induce protein misfolding and induce autophagy as a remedy for that. Exercise induces autophagy very potently because exercise damages the muscle, and autophagy is one of the processes that helps mitigate the damage that occurs during damage. Hypoxia potently induces autophagy. Tumors are well known to have hypoxia in the center.

title: The importance of autophagy in the brain and liver
content: In Japan, mouse strains that were made to be deficient in either of two essential autophagy genes (ATG5 or ATG7). In this experiment, they showed that once these mice are born, these autophagy-deficient newborn mice don’t survive more than a few hours. They fail to survive the neonatal starvation period because period between the cut-off of the placenta and suckling is a common feature in mammals and is potent induction of autophagy during that period.

title: Importance of autophagy to the brain
content: Autophagy is very important in the brain over the long term. Autophagy is keeping the toxicities that are driving neurodegeneration at bay. The brain is extremely autophagy dependent. Using Alzheimer’s disease specifically as an example, the brain undergoes increased apoptosis in a last ditch effort to survive. Autophagy stimulators are being generated as a remedy or as a means to delay neurodegenerative diseases.

title: Autophagy in different tissues
content: The liver is very sensitive to autophagy. A liver-specific knockout of an essential autophagy gene leads to fatty liver disease. Autophagy plays a role in preventing fat accumulation and accumulation of mallory bodies. The lungs looked relatively normal suggesting it’s not autophagy dependent.

title: The role of fasting in longevity
content: Fasting is one of the most potent stimulators of autophagy. The key to living longer is delaying the onset of chronic disease. Centenarians who are genetically gifted with tools to live longer, delay the onset of the disease, not live longer once they have the disease. Fasting plays an essential role in the mitigation of Alzheimer’s disease and metabolic disease.

title: Molecules that induce autophagy
content: Autophagy can be induced pharmacologically or chemically. Metformin, rapamycin, and other molecules that mimic fasting can induce autophagy. When mTOR activity is down, that’s a sign that we’re deficient in amino acids. We can also do that with rapamycin. When AMPK is up, that’s the cell being told we’re deficient in ATP. Another way that you can do that is to give Metformin.

title: Evidence for cancer treatment by blocking autophagy
content: Inhibiting autophagy in an adult mouse leads to death in 2-3 months from neurodegeneration. Targeting autophagy for cancer therapy would not be pointless.

title: Autophagy and Cancer
content: Autophagy plays a crucial role in cancer treatment. In a mouse model, when autophagy was turned off, the tumor died first. However, when autophagy was turned back on, the tissues were able to restore themselves back to normal. Kras-driven lung cancer and pancreatic cancer are highly autophagy-dependent, and the tumors are very susceptible to the functional loss of autophagy. There are a long list of cancers that are sensitive to autophagy, but the sensitivity is not all equal.

title: KRAS-Driven Cancers
content: KRAS is a GTP binding protein that is responsible for activating the MAP kinase pathway which is very key in driving cell proliferation. KRAS-driven lung cancer and pancreatic cancer are extraordinarily autophagy dependent. There are now drugs that target the cysteine residue of RAS, but they seem to be not durably effective in RAS-driven cancers because of the work-arounds.

title: The Autophagy Paradox
content: Cancer utilizes autophagy to survive, but autophagy is protective. A main function of autophagy in tissue homeostasis is to preserve cellular function to be normal, to prevent chronic damage and inflammation. And tissues that are susceptible to cancer as a result of chronic damage and inflammation, autophagy is highly protective. However, once you have a cancer, inhibiting autophagy is preferentially damaging to the tumor compared to the normal tissues.

title: Fasting and Chemotherapy
content: Fasting combined with chemotherapy may be superior to chemotherapy alone for cancer treatment. Calorie restriction takes away nutrients for the cancer to grow, and autophagy may also reduce inflammation.

title: Fasting and Autophagy
content: Fasting might be the most potent way to stimulate autophagy, more so than metformin or exercise. There are biotech companies working on pharmacological agents that can stimulate autophagy. After 7 days, autophagy is fully cranked. We also know that after 12 hours of fasting, autophagy is not stimulated. But in between those numbers is where it becomes much less clear. Peter's dream experiment would be the following: Get a tube of blood after a three day fast, a four day fast, a five day fast, a seven day fast, a 10 day fast, and send it to Eileen to get some sort of quantification of autophagy.

title: Peter's Fasting Experiments
content: After a 7 day fast, glucose plummets, insulin becomes unmeasurable, beta-Hydroxybutyric goes way up, uric acid doubles, and there are dramatic changes in the endocrine system. Gonadotropins go down. Peter noticed that after 3 days of fasting he sees all of the same things from a 7 day fast but just not to the same magnitude. Other things happening after 3 days: Glucose equilibrium, AMPK way up, mTOR must be way down, and protein deacetylation must be off.

title: Quantifying Autophagy
content: We NEED a 'signature' of autophagy, says Peter. Peter's dream experiment would be to get a tube of blood after a three day fast, a four day fast, a five day fast, a seven day fast, a 10 day fast, and send it to Eileen to get some sort of quantification of autophagy. Currently, from experiments in mice, we know that looking for LC3 proteins could help you see the formation of autophagosomes. If you tried to look for LC3 conversion from I to II in blood samples, it would be much more challenging.

title: Proposed experiment to find a signature for autophagy in humans
content: Hundred volunteers would fast for different periods of time (Three, four, five, six, seven days, et cetera.) and they each would be subject to blood draws and muscle biopsies. In the blood you could looks for things like…BHB, glucose, leucine, methionine, uric acid, then there’s probably a whole bunch of other small molecules and things in the proteome that we don’t know yet know. In rodents, Eileen has also already found that glucuronic acid accumulates when they inhibited autophagy. We could use metabolites as surrogate markers for the consequences of autophagy. Then you have the check, which is the muscle biopsy, which can give you some sort of quantifiable gradation.

title: Something Eileen plans to explore in rodents
content: A metabolic characterization of a wild type mouse fasted versus an autophagy-deficient mouse fasted. That would potentially identify the metabolic changes that were autophagy dependent. And I think that would provide some clues as to what to look at in humans.

title: Current knowledge gaps around fasting as a tool for longevity
content: Peter finds it “ridiculous” that more attention isn’t being dedicated to finding the proper dose and frequency of a tool as potent as fasting is to human health. He hopes that Eileen would be apart of helping him put that together. With his Fast Mimicking Diet (Prolon), Valter Longo asserts that it’s possible to get most of the benefit without actually having to be fully fasted, but to instead reduce your calories significantly for a period of five days. Maybe he’s right, but we have no idea. We have no idea what the efficacy of that approach is versus a total water only fast for five days. By about seven days into a prolonged fast, you pretty much reach a steady state. Consistent flux of triglyceride into free fatty acid out of the fat cell. Steady state level of beta-hydroxybutyrate, acetoacetate, and glucose, such that basically the sum total of them in millimolar concentrations is about preserved to where you would be non fasting. So it begs the question, if we posit that once you reach that steady state of seven to 10 days, you’re clearly in a fully turned on autophagy state, what’s the switch look like? The jugular question is: When you’re 24 hours or 48 hours or 72 hours into a fast, are you 80% of the way to the benefit or just 20%? Using fasting (as opposed to trying to find some pill you could take) seems like the easier thing to do. The irony? If you took 1% of the budget that is being dispensed to find pills to stimulate autophagy, we would actually be able to answer the fasting dose question clearly.

title: Nutritional intervention for cognitive impairment
content: You can take people that are in an early stage of cognitive impairment and delay it and or reverse it through that type of nutritional intervention. That doesn’t necessarily say autophagy is playing a role since other good things are happening like improving glucose and insulin signaling in the brain. At minimum, we’re really starting to see the impact of metabolism in the brain.

title: Rapamycin and autophagy
content: Rapamycin is a very potent inhibitor of mTOR. Presumably it induces some level of autophagy. Data suggests that rapamycin is neuroprotective. It’s the only molecule that has demonstrated a longevity benefit across all four models of eukaryotic cells. The question is: By what mechanism is it producing longevity? How much of that benefit is through autophagy? How much of it is through inhibition of senescent cells? What about the reduction of inflammation?

title: Fasting and metabolic health
content: There’s no question that when you improve metabolic health, which you can do through fasting, you reduce the risk of all of those significantly. The question then becomes: How much of a role does autophagy play in that? There’s a compelling case that autophagy is good for neurodegeneration and cancer. But, what about cardiovascular disease? Not much in the literature directly looking at autophagy and CVD. However, there are more than likely benefits from fasting (which inducing autophagy). Peter’s interpretation of things is that the benefits of fasting in CVD are primarily mediated through the metabolic health benefits of it.

title: Autophagy and cellular senescence
content: Evidence suggests that SASP (the secretion of inflammatory factors that occurs during senescence) is facilitated by autophagy. In the cancer setting, there’s also examples where loss of autophagy limits senescence.

title: Metformin and autophagy
content: In a fed state, if we give an animal or a human metformin, will it still induce autophagy through just the AMPK activation?

title: Autophagy and Metformin
content: But, we don’t understand over the long term what the consequences of having autophagy or not having autophagy actually is, says Eileen. In other words… What is the consequence of autophagy induction by metformin? It’s probably best to test that in a system where autophagy could be toggled up or down (rather than just on or off)

title: Rapamycin and Autophagy
content: Rapamycin has been studied liberally in everything from yeast, flies, worms, mammals. It uniformly extends life across all those organisms. It’s also a potent inhibitor of mTOR (which would signal autophagy, all things equal). Safety is the reason, says Eileen. It does other things such as suppress the immune system. Although that is dose dependent. In fact, this experiment showed rapamycin is actually immune enhancing when given intermittently. Why isn’t this being more highly promoted and used as an anti-aging molecule?

title: Fasting and Exercise as Longevity Tools
content: Pharma companies are hesitant to focus on drugs that are about “prevention”. And that fact makes a compelling case that for taking the best and safest drug of them all, which is fasting, and understanding how to dose it and what frequency to dose it. The same is true for exercise, says Peter. Most people need to simply do more exercise however it would be very valuable to understand the minimum effective amount. “So both from an exercise perspective and a nutrient deprivation perspective, there’s no more low hanging fruit in terms of minimizing human suffering and understanding how these things work.” —Peter Attia

title: Decoding the Metabolic Response to Nutrients
content: David Sabatini and Peter have discussed this possibility (although Peter says he won’t do it). But there’s an huge opportunity there because the metabolic response to nutrients is a black box. And there’s probably a multibillion dollar opportunity in decoding the black box. In other words, when we understand exactly what the response is to each different type of nutrient in every different dose and frequency and we can decode that in the way that we can do with so many other biochemical processes, you can do everything. There’s a drug development platform that comes out of that. But Peter is most interested in applying this knowledge into clinical practice with patients. The drug development side is high risk/effort but high reward. But there’s actually very little risk in doing proper studies to find an autophagy signature

title: The Nobel Prize for Autophagic Research
content: The 2016 Nobel Prize was awarded to Yoshinori Ohsumi for the genetic elucidation of autophagy

title: Autophagy and Cancer Therapy
content: Eileen would like to spend the coming years of her career translating what they’ve learned about the role of autophagy in cancer and that involves developing small molecule inhibitors to inhibit autophagy for cancer therapy. Eileen, along with Alec Kimmelman, have started a company that is currently focusing on defining at the molecular level what the functional requirements for autophagy are in individual cancers. This involves understanding the metabolic role of autophagy, i.e., Why does one cancer need autophagy more than another?

title: Autophagy and Inflammation
content: The newest connection is the connection between autophagy and inflammation. When you turn off autophagy, you stimulate inflammation. In the context of cancer, that can be a really good thing because the game changer in cancer therapy now is immune checkpoint blockade. One patient went through surgery, radiation, chemotherapy, and it all failed. Her body was riddled with tumors. She went on a clinical trial for immune checkpoint blockade and all the tumors melted away. In other words, people who don’t respond to the immune checkpoint blockade may respond to the inhibition of autophagy … “so that would be critically important to do”.

title: Autophagy and Immune Response
content: We know that tumors with a very high mutation burden respond better to immune checkpoint blockade. But it’s not that simple… because there are patients with tumors that do have a high mutation burden that don’t respond and we don’t know why. And then we also know there are tumors that have a low mutation burden that do respond. From there, they can ask questions like: How many mutations do you need? When you have a low mutation burden, what can you do to make the immune system see that tumor? Do you need only mutations in the nuclear genome? What about mutations in the mitochondrial genome? Next is to figure out the mechanism of response to immune checkpoint blockade to make cold tumors hot. And that’s essentially what the loss of autophagy is doing by promoting inflammation ⇒ it is taking a tumor that is not killed by T-cells, that does not respond to immune checkpoint blockade, and rendering that tumor responsive.

title: Autophagy and Immune Response
content: Autophagy seems to have a complicated relationship with the immune system. In the short term, inhibiting autophagy seems to improve the immune system's antitumorigenic response. However, in the long term, inhibiting autophagy can lead to dysfunctional T cells. The relationship between autophagy and innate immunity is also unclear. Peter Attia believes that we are still scratching the surface of the different ways autophagy impacts the body.

title: Fasting for Alzheimer's Prevention
content: Peter Attia believes that Alzheimer's disease prevention is an excellent opportunity to explore the benefits of fasting and enhancing autophagy. Currently, there is no way to treat or reverse Alzheimer's disease. Eileen notes that drugs have failed to treat Alzheimer's disease because they are trying to treat a symptom rather than the cause of the disease.

title: Future Study of Metabolism and Autophagy
content: Eileen is interested in exploring how autophagy impacts metabolism and identifying new targets for anti-cancer therapy. She also wants to keep pushing the field of immunotherapy forward. The technology has advanced to the point where we can understand metabolism in mammals at a level we've never seen before in various disease states. Eileen is also interested in figuring out the dose effect of fasting and a signature for autophagy.

title: Interest in Fasting
content: I am very much interested in fasting as a way to preserve health.

title: Importance of Diet
content: I’m also interested in the dietary part, because I think all of this has to go together. It’s not just how many calories you eat or how often you eat them, it’s what they are.
